column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

column2: Income or consumption share of the top 10%

column7: This is the income or consumption of the richest decile (tenth of the population) as a share of total income or consumption.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform - Income after tax or consumption
column7: P90 and P10 are the levels of income or consumption below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income or consumption.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income or consumption is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total income or consumption of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

column4: P90 is the the level of income or consumption below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income or consumption below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.
column11: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP) (2022)

column4: P90 is the the level of income or consumption above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income or consumption below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

column4:
The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P90 is the the level of income below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P90 is the the level of income above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is post-tax national income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column2: Wealth share of the richest 0.01% (Net national wealth) (WID)
column4:
This is the wealth of the richest 0.01% as a share of total wealth.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column2: Wealth share of the richest 0.001% (Net national wealth) (WID)
column4:
This is the wealth of the richest 0.001% as a share of total wealth.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

P90 is the the level of wealth below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of wealth below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

P90 is the the level of wealth above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of wealth below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

P50 is the median – the level of wealth below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of wealth below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total wealth of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.
